content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This game is so frustrating and pointless when it starts, but when u reach Hatmandor, its totally a different, that is when the real game starts.As for the game mechanics, the magic is creative- you can experiment with spells,tons of variety in items.Beautiful ambience,various types of enemiesThe only downsides are that-Weird interface and inventory system, but you get used to that.-For some, the horse riding may seem irritating(the horse riding is realistic-that is how horse riding should be in a game)-Controls are weird,kinda unresponsive (XBOX 360 controller recommended)Despite of the above flaws, I find it easy to lose myself in this game. I'm sure this game isn't for everyone, but if you love a good fantasy RPG I doubt you will be disappointed by Two Worlds II.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												YES! I most certainly recommend this game!!there is so much to do in this game, so much to explore that would defo create a very unique gameplay.I started to like action RPGs after playing Elder Scrolls Skyrim, and as I finished the game I was looking for something similar, and well.. I found this game.I was not very sure about this game, it starts very bland but put a few hours to it and you would love it.the cities are bigger than the Skyrim's towns, its a free-to-explore, open world RPG and its massive!the story is very good and the game is addictive, a true solid RPG.there are a few problems though, some dialogues with NPCs are a little bland, the horse riding is stupid and the menus are a tad confusing.dont get me wrong, after a few hours you would start to enjoy it and it can be a good replacement for elder scrolls series.combat is very good and fun, magic is awesome, crafting and forging is very good and you have all the cool stuff like alchemy, enchanting (sort of!), upgarding weapons and customizing your character.there are guilds to join, and tons of quests to do.dungeons, demons, undead creatures, necromancers, everything you would want from a RPG.take my advice and buy it, you will love it as much as I do!oh, and i almost forgot; this game has a true FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT!!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												I like the magic system in this game better than the one in Skyrim . You can preset five different spells, and switch between them without stopping the action . You need a staff to use magic, but you can also use the staff defensively to hit your opponents . You make your own spells by organizing what looks like Tarot cards into amulets .... The armor looks better, after you spend some money, but the archer's clothing still looks like something Uncle Joe wouls buy at the local sporting goods store .... There's a bit of humor in the game, and plenty of dungeons .... The inventory system can be confusing at first, because of the (quick switch) system that allows you to change between mage, archer, and fighter instantly .... A spell and a puff of smoke for that (quick switch) would make it more believable .... For some reason, the thieves guild gives you the best prices on any gear .... Don't upgrade weapons and armor too much at first, because the stuff you collect as the game progresses is much much better ....The music is highly atmospheric .... Those stiff hand jesticulations that characters make when talking remind me of cheap old kung fu movies Ha Ha .

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag to tell the truth. Massive amount of content which promise hours and hours of gameplay, that is if one is willing to overlook its flaws which make the game a chore to trudge through. Customization is fair although the single player campaign isn't as lenient and exciting as the multiplayer character customization. Combat is clunky at best and weapons dont have any weight to them, although the magic system makes up for it that is if the player is willing to be a mage above all else. There are a variety of enemies to fight against which makes combat refreshing despite the controls and horrid physics. Character models look stiff and unfinished although at times they look great (in cutscenes), maybe its the fact that the arms look really weird and unfinished. Voice acting is bearable most of the time although your character can get annoying at times. Action is pretty much average to say the most, story is decent, Two Worlds II isn't exactly going to be everyone's cup of tea but its a decent game in its own right. 6/10.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												After hearing how horrible this was in all the years since its release, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this game. The voice acting is terrible, the combat is weird at times, and the context sensitive keys seem like a useless relic from console porting, but this game feels like the first Witcher, but without timed button press combat. so far much of what I have been doing is following a tiny main quest thread and running around killing monsters for people. I'm a total sucker for games with a crafting system, and even though this one is kind of bare bones(only item improvements; no actual item creation) it is still fairly rewarding. Another huge bonus somewhat related to this is that your armor actually changes when you equip new pieces. It isn't just 8 reskinned versions of the same armor ala Dragon Age: Origins. Every set so far feels like a unique and interesting enough looking piece of armor. Cloaks abound, with decent cloth physics, though I have seen one scene where the cloak was draped across a character's body the wrong way, clipping through his chest and draping over his front. I'm playing this game with the Worldmerge mod, since I have the DLC and it is reportedly more immersive this way. The game looks amazing with DX10. Whenever I launch it with DX9 it just looks fuzzy in comparison. There is a huge amount of realistic plantlife dotting the landscape. It makes grassy fields in skyrim look like child's play. After putting it off for such a long time, I feel absolutely blown away by this game.Edit: the ending is a little confusing and kind of a let down. Just...be prepared for nearly nothing to be explained.

												For anyone doubting how bad the DRM for this game is, and whether it being on sale means it might be worth getting anyway, I implore you not to. The fact that they demand to know your full name, location (right down to the street you live on) and gender before even allowing you to play the game is absolutely obscene. Irrespective of the games quality there is no excuse to enforce such intrusive business practices on consumers. Spend your money elsewhere, and hopefully the turd that is DRM will go away eventually.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												First, the game does have its issues.  Nothing like running down a hill and taking enough fall damage to kill you, but if you press jump you can take a 50 foot jump with no damage.  Just weird and inconsistent.  And yes, you have to enter a key when you first run the game or get a DLC for the game, which is unusual and annoying at this point in time.  That being said, the land is interesting and fun, there are tons of creatures, a lot of flexibility with the story line but the biggest plus is the magic system.  You make your own spells from components and rearange the components later to suit other needs.  For instance I have created spells that shoot out a spray of missiles. The missiles blind when they hit and summon undead warriors where they land.  Another shoots a huge spray of fire missiles which bounce around filling an area with fiery death.  I've used water walking and feather fall to weasle my way into areas that, later, I realized I was supposed to get to later in the game, yet I was able to make it work.Another oddity of the game, which from my perspective, Im not sure is a plus or a minus is the multiplayer.   It has multiplayer, but unlike other games where you play the same game single and multiplayer the multiplayer game is a different game.   Same game mechanics but you gather in a city, and choose a storyline that has nothing to do with the single player game, gather your comrades and play through that scenario.  On one hand its extended, unique game play.  On the other you cant use the single player character you built up, you dont get to explore the extensive single player world and questlines with a friend and the multiplayer game has much less content.  I can still say I've had fun in multiplayer and built up a powerful multiplayer character, but its worth noting that when you read that the game is multiplayer its probably not executed the way you probably think it is. All in all I've enjoyed it an think its a game well worth exploring.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												There are a lots of improvements since Two Worlds 1, graphics is now awesome, the terrain, and vegetation doesn't have repetitive rock/field textures, the maps are big, tons of quests are waiting for the player to complete them, i solved all i've found, took me 65 hours to finish everything, which is not too long, and not too short time. The quality of quests are various, there are some traditional kill x creature ones too, bring potions, etc, but overall were entertaining. Some bugs in quests made some headache. The fighting system is not a big deal, but the crafting system allows to upgrade and recycle weapons, the armor sets can be mixed colored, shaped for the player's tastes. The multiplayer doesn't worth a word.Music tracks are nicely composed, brings more color in the game, and the story is not ending here! However, the TW3 is on hold atm, since devs have other games in development, personally i can't wait to see what will happen next.

 My Review On Two Worlds II This is the worst game ever, I have spent god knows how long trying to play this game.First things first, I went to play this game since I liked the first one and saw thiswas cheap so I bought it, however after successfully installing and downloading it, it wouldn't run, after launch it would just not open a window or anything, so I looked on the forum and it said try restarting steam so I did that, it didn't work, it also said try restarting your computer, so I did that, didn't work, twenty minutes after it started to work, then it asked me for all this stpid information after I just bought the game asking me to buy even more things just so taht I can play it, and it would seem that apparently I PAID to play the stupid demo of a game that is years old. Overall this is the worst game ever, and forcing  someone to fill in their personal details such as their exact location and proxy server should be illegal in which some cases it is, I will never download or play any game from these devs ever again, and I say this for all gamers, stop this miss conduct. content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game was involving, had some nice RPG mechanics (interesting alchemy, smithing and magic), and was overall fun to play.That's not to say it didn't have problems, it had loads of them. But amazingly, all those problems worked towards making the game an enjoyable experience!- It had loads of janky voicing- my characters creepy laughter and the game's habit of cutting off audio dialogue if it was very long (like someone overloading me on exposition) with the next dialogue line gave my character a sort of sleazy funny personality, similar little things with other characters.- It had weird little bugs and glitches that helped with the gameplay (some seriously hard enemies I beat by exploiting this).- Awkwardly half-naked models (that the player awkwardly flirted with) and a story that probably tried to take itself too seriously gave loads of funny moments.So it might not have been a great game in the way the developers would have wanted it to be, but it is definitely recommendable for what it became.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												It's not as clean and polished as most other games, but it has a lot of great elements taken from games such as Skyrim, Diablo, Assassin's Creed, and many others. It had (and still has with this year's [2016] big update coming) the potential to be a better game than all the rest surprisingly, but it seemed to fall short in many aspects. I love the items, map, NPC interactions, enemies, and especially the leveling and magic systems! Plus the difficulty feels just right and the game is seriously funny as it never takes itself too seriously, but the combat completely falls short in it's glitchiness, and story falls far, far, FAR short as it's simply complete garbage.... but still, the core game has a sort of magic to it that keeps you playing and enjoying it overall.You can see I've had to say "but" a whole lot in this review after trying to praise Two Worlds II, BUT if you can overlook some of it's shortcomings, and enjoy the parts where it shines, it's a very fun game for $21.99.

												This game is kind of like Skyrim's red headed step-child who had a make-over. It is somewhat entertaining in that it is a RPG experience. I just quickly lost any attraction to it as the game is pretty empty story-wise (simple, not much emotion, written for 12 year olds). While the graphics look decent, the animation just looks stiff and somewhat lifeless.I did like how they handled archery. I also liked how the loot system worked. I have a lot of games that are just better in every way though.All of that being said, it is currently $1.99. If you are hard up for a RPG, it is easily worth that much.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												First, the game does have its issues.  Nothing like running down a hill and taking enough fall damage to kill you, but if you press jump you can take a 50 foot jump with no damage.  Just weird and inconsistent.  And yes, you have to enter a key when you first run the game or get a DLC for the game, which is unusual and annoying at this point in time.  That being said, the land is interesting and fun, there are tons of creatures, a lot of flexibility with the story line but the biggest plus is the magic system.  You make your own spells from components and rearange the components later to suit other needs.  For instance I have created spells that shoot out a spray of missiles. The missiles blind when they hit and summon undead warriors where they land.  Another shoots a huge spray of fire missiles which bounce around filling an area with fiery death.  I've used water walking and feather fall to weasle my way into areas that, later, I realized I was supposed to get to later in the game, yet I was able to make it work.Another oddity of the game, which from my perspective, Im not sure is a plus or a minus is the multiplayer.   It has multiplayer, but unlike other games where you play the same game single and multiplayer the multiplayer game is a different game.   Same game mechanics but you gather in a city, and choose a storyline that has nothing to do with the single player game, gather your comrades and play through that scenario.  On one hand its extended, unique game play.  On the other you cant use the single player character you built up, you dont get to explore the extensive single player world and questlines with a friend and the multiplayer game has much less content.  I can still say I've had fun in multiplayer and built up a powerful multiplayer character, but its worth noting that when you read that the game is multiplayer its probably not executed the way you probably think it is. All in all I've enjoyed it an think its a game well worth exploring.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												I'm not going to pretend this game is great, it even borders on bad at times but if youre a big wrpg fan you might let some of the bad things slide and see it for what it does well.Controls are clunky and animations are stiff, but the Gameplay is solid and character progression is good, you have 3 options in how you handle combat, ranged, melee and magic, ranged is probably the worst but i didn't really experience much of it, melee is fairly basic but the skills you can get make it a little better with time, i didn't start to enjoy it until i started parrying(hitting just after blocking) and using my skills more.Magic is insanely good in this game, it works by combining different effect cards with different elements to create your own spells, i'm not sure how many spells there are in the game but a lot of them are pretty unique and creative.The story is pretty average apart from the ending, i don't want to spoil it but the last boss is really dissapointing since you don't even fight him head on.Sidequests on the other hand are great and reminded me of oblivion in some ways, although not nearly as good, you have different guilds that have different storylines that vary in length and then there are a bunch of quests in the world that are both interesting and even pretty funny at times.Graphically it's a mixed bag, aesthetically it's great, the enviroments are varied and pretty unique for a wrpg, you go from an egyptian savannah area to some sort of asian(Korean or Chinese) jungle and finally to a swamp, the assets and environments are good looking but other aspects like animations and character models are pretty bad.One final thing to note is that you have to register an account at the beggining of the game to use the multiplayer, the registration is incredibly intrusive and personal if i remember correctly and i saw that a lot of people marked the game as not reccomended because of it, which i consider completely justified, if you however decide to try the mp(and that's if it's still online)you're going to get a pretty great psuedo mmo tier experience with loads of content and even a village manager later on.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Two Worlds II gets rid of the best part of Two Worlds - exploration. The original game was a rough RPG, it had many flaws, but it was the exploration that made it a decent game. The sequel is no longer open world, and instead it focuses on storyline, which however, is as bad as in the first game. The NPCs are just as shallow, and the combat remains the same - okay, but nothing special. In consequence, we are left with a game that is average at best, because the excitement of discovering new areas is dimnished by the fact that everything is led by the story, and hence the player cannot go sideways, try to fight much more powerful enemies in hope of much better loot than he is supposed to find. Two Worlds II becomes just an average game with nothing special. I would recommend it only for those who already completed Two Worlds and other good RPGs and have nothing to play. It's okay to kill some time, however, not really worth much. Two Worlds II is a huge disappointment. Instead of improving gameplay in the sequel, developers took away the only thing that made the original game good.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												The game is great. I find it rather funny and entertaining, and my only complaint is the framerate.I'm gonna be apologetic about some things that others have criticized:The voice acting: It's not that bad. Certainly better than the majority of anime dubs out there, and really, it's pretty much on par with the voice acting in Skyrim. Which while no huge feat, is still kind of the industry standard.The dialogue:Is it perfect? No. But it is pretty dang funny. The charatcers are full of quips and one-liners with a lot of homages (You're a little short for a City Guard aren't you?) and a LOT of self-mockery, especially directed at the previous game in the series, which are subtle, but you'll catch if you play them back to back.The fighting:It's pretty straight forward attack-button mashing mostly. But when you do come up against particularly tough opponents you can usually find some way to beat them. Otherwise: go level up. It's an RPG. So of course the mobs that are hard at the beginning (Varns: which are Mummy III army of Anubis style jackal-men) become paper thin foes by 6 hours in. The plot:Save the girl. Defeat the evil Emperor. Bad guys from the first game are now the good guys. Pretty standard. Is that bad? I don't think so. It's still an enjoyable story. If you're looking a novel, complex plotline, GO READ A BOOK! It's all plot and no grind! Want suggestions? Message me, I'll give you lists. So unless you're looking to be blown away by some unexpected seldom-before-seen tale of intrigue, wizardry, and shenanigans, it's a good story.As for the sidequest stories. They're ridiculously over the top, asinine, or just straight up obvious comedic relief. One mercenary mission request is a parent and daughter locked in a cellar because there are angry ostriches trying to kill the daughter by touching her with their feathers and causing an allergic reaction. They sent the letter by carrier pidgeon. Is this serious? Clearly not. To those saying the game's stories are stupid: lighten up. Laugh at the game. Laugh at the genre. They're really picking on RPGs as a genre in this game.The mechanics:Plays like a hack'n'slash brawler. I like hack'n'slash brawlers. It can be a bit clunky at times, with your character sometimes crouch to sneak instead of running for his life, but you can fix that by changing the key-bindings I believe.Lastly, the Personal Info requirements:It's your name and address. All public information anyway. All information you've already put into Steam likely more than once. Do you really the Polish game designers care that much about you that they're going to stalk you, or ruin their business by stealing your identity? Or send you snailmail? No. It's for commercial data collection. Statistics. By knowing your address, age, and sex, they can precisely gauge who is buying their stuff and adjust marketing accordingly. That's it.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												After learning about confirmed Two World 3 and upcomming update to engine and new DLC for Two Worlds 2 I decided to play this game again (Need to finally try out rolling a wizard. They have wizard hats, so... yeah...)Lot of people will think this game is not really good. And yes, it's missing a lot. Animations some times can look... weird... Voice acting... Not the worst, some characters voiced just... Boring. Like with the idea of "lets just finish this". It's not terrible just without much of the emotion, makes its sound flat and boring. Character models can look pretty lame too.What's bad too, is that you can't go to multiplayer continent in singleplayer. And by that I mean, in multiplayer there is different island and it's not that small. And while playing singleplayer when opening map you can see that next huge island and you have this "oohhhhh yeahhhh" but later you notice that you just finished game and didn't even played there, turns out - multiplayer only.But the good thing is, theres lots of stuff to do. There's DLC too, that adds new map and stuff. Didn't even started playing that myself (whats bad about it, your character is voiced by different person and it's more annoying than the old one. But when you exploring and collecting stuff he uses lines from the main game "oh, what is this?" and other exploration lines that are voiced by the old voice actor, so it's sounds weird with 2 different voices).......................................................................................................................In the end I wanted to talk about DRM. It is bad and annoying, but Im not sure if most people who review and give negative rating with "Key doesn't work" are stu... Lets just call them... Special... Or what. I reinstalled game lot's of times, re-entered key every time I reisntalled game, just did that today too. Everything works well every time, never had single problem with activation. Key works EVERY TIME. Im not sure what people are doing to mess everything up. JUST REGISTER YOUR KEY TO YOUR EMAIL, IF YOU ENTERING KEY FOR THE FIRST TIME. AFTER THAT, IN CASE YOU ARE ASKED TO ENTER KEY AGAIN, JUST ENTER KEY AND DON'T USE "REGISTER GAME" CHECK-BOX, SO YOU DON'T GET INVALID KEY MESSAGE.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												After 32 hours of gameplay I'm still playing this game and I don't know why. The actual gameplay is fun, but it still has so many problems. I found one game-breaking bug that trapped me in a dungeon, but I was able to get out with console commands. I can no longer stand to hear any of the dialog; the voice acting and script are both so bad.I also sailed to the largest island in the game, only to find out you can't go to it - if you happen to make it in it teleports you back to the shore. It takes a fair bit of time to get there, so don't waste your time trying. You can only go to the small islands on the map.And because I spent some time exploring around before doing missions I'm an unstoppable death machine with no equal in combat - it's starting to make things a bit boring due to the lack of challenge.-------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW:I wish I could even play this game. It took a half hour of searching the internet for a way to get the game to even launch and when it did start working, it wasn't due to anything I did because I hadn't changed anything - merely tried to launch it a few more times and then it spontaneously worked (as far as I can tell). Then, once it was running, it kept crashing every few minutes. On top of all of that, they have the balls to put advertisements in the game to try to sell you other things. It also forced all control to my 360 controller I had plugged in without giving me an option to switch to mouse control, which somehow made registration impossible because I couldn't pick a gender."Infuriating" is a rather kind description of my experience with this game so far. I'd like to play it, and I'm going to continue to try for a little while, but after fighting to get it to work at all for this long I simply can't recommend it to anyone.-------------------------------------------------EDIT: Bandicam appears to have been what was causing it to crash. not sure why it wouldn't start up at first. The game is fun, but lips don't match dialog and characters move in cutscenes as if they were marionets. Dialog seems to jump around randomly between subjects sometimes and every now and then it just skips itself mid-sentence as if it expects you were bored.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I love this game, played it through completely at least twice.  Bought 2 copies, this one for my steam library.  Be aware that many of the negative reviews of this game are based solely upon the (quite legitimate) concerns about intrusive DRM, which we all kinda despise, especially as Steam users we aught not to be subjected to it.  That aside, once the monkey hoops are jumped through, this is an absolutely marvellous game.+ The graphics are amazing and the environments are some of the most beautiful and best of any game I have played, in face I would say THE best.  The savannah is amazing, totally atmospheric, feels like a real savannah aught to, and the Japanese-style college of magick is also gorgeous.  Like something from a dream the designer had and they made it real.  It might be a little dated now, though, that was my impression playing this back few years ago.+ The enemies are not level scaled, which I really like.  Some are very tough and cant be defeated at the start of the game, necessitating going back after your character has levelled a little.  I really like this mechanic, although some folks I know want every enemy to be beatable at any level, like in Bethesda games, which I always usually get bored of as partway through the game your character is more powerful than the game curve and every enemy is toast even on highest difficulty.  So thumbs up to Two Worlds for this, and I hope to see tough, non level-scaled enemies in Two Worlds 3 also.There are lots of other great things in this game but these are the 2 that really stick in my mind.  Horses and boats are great also come to think of it.Anyway this game should be getting 90%+ I think on recommendations, its being brought down by the DRM unfortunatley, but IMHO it's well worth jumping through the hoops to play this amazing game.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Tbh I went into this thinking this game was going to be terrible. Hearing about the 1st was like reading a good horror novel. Many stories all with terrible outcomes and pretty much a constant census....it was a beyond crappy Elder scrolls copy. Naturally with that mass of "don't do it" you would think it's sequel wouldn't be that much better....apparently that was incorrect. Everyone said this was a light year jump compared to the last. Never played the 1st so I wouldn't know but I can say whole heartedly this is a good game. Even though I couldn't verify my code to start the game for a day or so (until I learned Norton was blocking stuff), even though this game lagged at the very start at the dungeon section (updated drivers? idk just started running smoothly after that even though the drivers were for hardline optimization...) and even though for some reason I couldn't skip the start up intro a few times....even with all those headaches this game has turned out amazing. Magic system was confusing as fudge but it's pretty sweet, pretty large world, dialogue is quite funny, quests don't seem too mundane and not a single gameplay issue really (aside for a few slow downs a few mintues ago and a brief freeze.) Overall I think this is a very good game.Best way to sum it up would be to compare it to....Saints Row. Two Worlds 2 is the Saints Row to  Skyrims GTA. Pretty sure I didn't world that properly....but what I mean is Two worlds is like Saints Row while Skyrim is GTA. It's not as refined and polished as it's competition and not fully as serious and more cartoony BUT that doesn't mean it doesn't have it's own fun and uniqueness about it.

content:

Product received for free
												I've bought Two Worlds and I ware satisfied with the game, so when I saw it I can grab this one from dlh platform for free I haven't though about it twice.I'm from Poland so you can probably say I'm not fully objective, still I enjoyed this game (played in offline mode), and I'm planning to play it again.People said that the quest system is boring as well as lecturers, but for me this was an enjoyable experience. Also it is said the game has a poor difficulty curve. With that I must agree unfortunately. The start for me was hard, but after I've acquired perks and increased my skill, my bow become deadly almost to everything without serious effort, with the except of the final battle of course, which was way to hard IMHO. This is not Skyrim I must agree, but still this is fine game. The story is ok. Crafting system is improved from first part and it makes far more sense and weapons are no longer ill overpowered. I really enjoyed horse races and I find horses to be far better presented then in Skyrim to be honest.  The 20 dollar tag seems quite much, fortunately this game lands on sales, or giveaways very often and I highly recommend this one.   Btw. watch out for new DLC that is coming out (Call of the Tenebrae). The producer promised that it will improve game graphic significantly with this one.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Two Worlds II gets rid of the best part of Two Worlds - exploration. The original game was a rough RPG, it had many flaws, but it was the exploration that made it a decent game. The sequel is no longer open world, and instead it focuses on storyline, which however, is as bad as in the first game. The NPCs are just as shallow, and the combat remains the same - okay, but nothing special. In consequence, we are left with a game that is average at best, because the excitement of discovering new areas is dimnished by the fact that everything is led by the story, and hence the player cannot go sideways, try to fight much more powerful enemies in hope of much better loot than he is supposed to find. Two Worlds II becomes just an average game with nothing special. I would recommend it only for those who already completed Two Worlds and other good RPGs and have nothing to play. It's okay to kill some time, however, not really worth much. Two Worlds II is a huge disappointment. Instead of improving gameplay in the sequel, developers took away the only thing that made the original game good.

												This game has great graphics and caracters, Unfortunatly the difficulty is WAY to much, I just keep encountering barryer after barryer to gameplay.... This is one of those games where the story cant flow becasue i keep getting stuck and dieding hundreads of times at certain parts. Also you cant delete old saves, so after a while it gets hard to figure out wich one is correct, also the saves appear to have No order to how they are listed, further increasing how much of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥this game is. If you try nd go where the game doesent want you to, you encounter OP mobs that can one shot your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ caracter who, even though he has enough money cannot buy Steel armor because your not a high enough level. This game is full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and although it could be immersive, there is nothing immersive about dieing 20 times to get through a gate guarded by 6 wolfmen, or pausing it to guzzle health potions, and then running out and dieing anyway...  And although it says its "OPEN WORLD" it might as well not be, casue this game is full of narrow passes you have to go through. making it feel Not open in any way. Also Horses are compleatly useless, they are slower then running on foot. For some reason my caracter can run 60MPH even carrying armor and a big shield. My caracter looks like a teenager but sounds like batman in the dark knight movie... THis game basicly sucks. Im tired of having to go outsde the game to look up how other people got through this♥♥♥♥♥♥... even on easy this is still the hardest RPG ive ever played.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												 Two Worlds 2 is a game that is pretty much unfinished. How do I know? The map, the story, the map. I first played the original Two Worlds back in 07. The game was strange to sat the least. The story felt unfinished with entire cities not even used within the story. There was a lack of polish but it did feel like an journey, as well as offered some new things for it's time. Now the 2nd one. Eh...  So at first it seems more polished. The story feels more a part of the game world and not just an after thought. The story is still weak. Your character has to save his sister again, while getting transported to different areas for whatever reason. The story also starts and ends all of the sudden.   Gameplay wise it is a third person hack n slash. Nothing wrong, nothing good either. The boats are nice but needless due to the world mostly being shut off from you openly exploring. Horses are also lame since you only use them on smallish islands.  Sound is ehh. Voice actors try, but their tones don't fit their scenes. Think Oblivion with even less feeling. Graphics are decent for 2011, not on par with Witcher 2 but also no where near as demanding. I play this game at Ultra except AA @2160p 60fps no dips on a 4790k/980ti. The performance is great. Visual options are fairly vast and some advanced setting as well.  The game world is dull and much smaller than the first game. You have a semi large island and two smaller islands. There is a huge hunk of land in the middle of the map but you can not get on it. Atleast not center of it. It is reserved for multiplayer. What a load. You can sail around for hours in a boat, that if you get it stuck on rocks you're stuck. This a mostly empty world.  Atleast they got rid of the old english from the last game. All in all this is a skipable boring RPG. Get Witcher 3, Skyrim, or beer instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												*Note: I do not *not* reccomend it, but instead I cannot say it's most enjoyable. Due to Steam lacking a neutrual option, despite much ask for it, I mean lean towards this part of the black and white system it has.Review start:The game is, sadly, not as good as the first. It has a good idea for a system, but doesn't do to well. It heavily reminds me of the first Assassins Creed, with the graphics and how running works. Sadly though it doesn't have the good features of it.The combat has changed, and now defensive combat isn't the same, but instead an actual blocking mechanic. The downside is that it doesn't actually block but reduce damage. The magic system and bows have changed for the better, though meele is now worse.When it comes to meele, there is no longer a dodge back mechanic. The block system was instead put in as a replacement, but it fails because like before, it only reduces damage without the overpowered benifits. The idea was good though, and I'd like to see a more realistic version of it in the next game. If it was more so fast-paced realistic combat compared to full on fantasy I think the combat system would be amazing, and work more with the design it has.It still suffers from the RPG sickness most games have, where you are forced to upgrade gear all the time or die. That is annoying for the fact it restricts how much you can customize yourself.Early game it is hard, and unclear why so to many people. Some enemies can be defeated, others cannot with no indication. It doesn't help that your also very weak at the start.One annoying thing that caused me to like the game less is how, right now, to advance in the story I must travel on road, yet the dog people (Forgot the name) are placed right where I must go. It wouldn;t be bad, if i could actually attack them. Not only do their shamans have a cloak that kills me faster then I can attack, but shooting them is useless as they heal faster then you can damage. There is also no limit to their mana for some reason.The inventory is screwed up, or at least the keybindings are now, as it's akward to reach over to F1-7 all the time and memorize it. The old inventory was fine, as items were easy to spot and everything was neat and organized I would say.This is all I have to say for now, and it may change as I play some more, but for now it's a netural leaning towards a sale price. Also if Steam ever adds an actual netural option, as people want, I'll fix the review.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												When this game was released, a friend and I played it but exclusively for the co-op adventure so we could be together. I can't think of a greater injustice. The games Multiplayer \ co-op features are merely a glimpse into what this game has to offer. After years I've thankfully come back to play it, and the single-player RPG is absolutely fantastic. From the markets of Hatmandor, across the archipelago in my own sailboat to the University at Ashos; I love this game. Multiplayer is fun, co-op is great; but single-player is where this game really shines. The graphics hold up tremendously, the music is wonderful, and while some of the voice-acting isn't top-notch; it's light years beyond the first Two Worlds game. I absolutely recommend playing through this campaign. Any RPG fan will adore it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2013
												Two Worlds 2 можно порекомендовать в качестве реабилитационной терапии после недавней Готики. Она на самом деле лучше, прилизаннее, лишена чудовищных багов. Для многих она подействовала действительно как бальзам на душу. К несчастью, при всем старании разработчиков убрать недостатки предыдущей части новые «элементы» резво бьют по рукам, отбивая желание знакомства с этим безумно неудобным шаблонным миром. Спасти ситуацию мог мультиплеер, однако он заведомо обречен на провал. Сервера пустуют. Мультиплеер первой части являлся настоящим пристанищем лагов и читеров, и, несмотря на все заверения, Two Worlds 2 унаследовала все эти черты. Чего стоит только тот факт, что статы игроков хранятся на локальных компьютерах. Несложно представить последствия этой ситуации. Все, что есть в Two Worlds 2 – прилизанное визуальное оформление и отсутствие багов. Последнее на сегодняшний день – настоящая редкость, так что этот факт может являться стимулом для прохождения игры до конца, в том случае если закрыть глаза на неадекватный интерфейс и пустые диалоги. RealityPump «перестарались» – других слов для подведения итога попросту не найти.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Holy s**t this is a terrible game.  Lets start off with the beginning.  Why does a game want my name, address, birthdate, and gender?  Blatant refusal to give out all that for a game, so I now live at 69 Nope Rope Avenue.  Secondly is the immersion.  Granted, I had read the reviews before purchasing so I was prepared for a dud, but this is aweful.  You can never go wrong with the cudgel.  You don't even have to hit them and they'll take damage.  When a spell or arrow hits, the sounds and animations are off enough to make you wonder if you actually hit the targets or not.  As for aiming, with magic there's no need.  Just spin around until the purple circle highlights an enemy and fire away, through your body if need be.  Voice acting is meh, but that they tried to animate the lips and bodies to match, but missed the mark entirely is just irritating.  At this point a text dialogue would have been better.Third is the story, or how much I could get through without contemplating burning my PC just for some entertainment.  It's dull and lifeless.  Somebody got kidnapped, and somebody wants you to save them, and you're important but we can't say why, of and I can see the future so trust me.  Might not have been so bad, but the story never ends.  Run from one room to another, and you'll get stopped by some triggered story time.  I barely get to kill two enemies before it's time to listen to someone else ramble on about something that ultimately devolves into fetch and kill quests.So why did I buy this game?  The magic creation system.  I was told it was advanced, and from the gameplay videos it interested me enough to drop $20 (with a coming refund).  Let me tell you know, it sucks.  You first need to unlock skills by finding items, and then you need to find items to craft the skills, and then you need to spend resources to cast the skills.  Maybe if in the first hour you got more than two spells, it could be enough to draw you in, but nope.  Here's a game that lets you craft anything, kind of, with limited variability.So no, don't buy this thing.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												When this game was released, a friend and I played it but exclusively for the co-op adventure so we could be together. I can't think of a greater injustice. The games Multiplayer \ co-op features are merely a glimpse into what this game has to offer. After years I've thankfully come back to play it, and the single-player RPG is absolutely fantastic. From the markets of Hatmandor, across the archipelago in my own sailboat to the University at Ashos; I love this game. Multiplayer is fun, co-op is great; but single-player is where this game really shines. The graphics hold up tremendously, the music is wonderful, and while some of the voice-acting isn't top-notch; it's light years beyond the first Two Worlds game. I absolutely recommend playing through this campaign. Any RPG fan will adore it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												+ Reworked combat places emphasis on action over animation. Deeper magic system+ Good quest variety+ Music is still great, voice acting is improved+ Lots of minigames that adhere to the experience~ Armor and weapons can no longer be upgraded endlessly~ Alchemy no longer has any negative effects. Once you can make a good channeling potion, you'll forget what dying was like~ Texture quality is improved, but everything else looks awkward. There is way too much bloom and motion blur~ Horse control is improved, but mounted combat is gone. Enemies can now be run over~ Quests now use automatic map markers to show the way. Though it's nice to see where I have to go, I found myself rarely having to actually think to complete quests. It's an imperfect solution that could have been solved through better writing- Game is short and linear. Main quest must now be done in specific order. 4 chapters, and the last 2 can be done in about an hour each. Game tries to cover this up by having a steep difficulty curve. It makes sidequests feel compulsory, as this is where most xp can be found. Boosting your level this way is the only way to make the main quest a fair challenge- Map is much more limited than it looks. Large amounts of land and sea have little of interest and/or are inaccesible. A lot of the time that I've logged on the game has been simply to explore areas that I later found were pointless to explore- Stupid AI. Got a bounty for defending myself in a city. Many enemies can be safespotted- Lots of glitches. That bounty I just mentioned; I got it for fighting back against a character who was supposed to stop asking me for money after a quest. Quest ended, and whenever I got too close to him, I had to choose whether to pay him or fight himOverall, it's sort of "meh". Drops the ball on a lot of the stuff that the first game did fine, while introducing mechanics that feel fresh and more user-friendly. Not sure whether I recommend it, unless you also plan on getting the DLC, in which case it's definitely worth a try.

												I wanted my money back 20 minutes into the game. The only thing salvagable i got from the bundle package was the tower defense. I think the trailer made it look much more glamerous and made it out to be much more than it really is. The gameplay looked good, but there was no option to setup a controller. Also I do not like the multiplayer. One thing in particular was haveing to bring up a menu to leave the city gates. Another was the life regeneration skill only worked if you wasn't in fighting stance. I could understand haveing to change stances if the fighting stance had an ill affect on friendly NPC's, could accindently perform an attack on one, or change the attitude of a potential enemy. In my opinion they had good intentions, but the game lack a sort of uniqueness that draws a player in.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												This was a very solid RPG with tons of great gameplay and at a discounted price it's a fantastic buy. The last part of the game isn't as filled out as the rest of the game, but that seems to be a design issue as much as anything else. As with most RPGs, the real joy of the game is getting there. The magic system is original and flexible (possibly to the point of being overpowered), bow and standard combat is decent but not groundbreaking.  I really enjoyed a lot of the characterization. The horses are a bit of a disappointment, but you really only have to use it for one part. The free expansion is even kinda fun, though I wished it was harder and longer. Thats what she said.

												I'm going to be blunt here. The multiplayer CAN be fun, with friends of course, if you can look past the "dark" story, and forget about what you are supposedly questing for, having some friends in this can make it much more enjoyable, its loot system is intresting, and magic can get crazy with enough planning. Another positive point is the crafting system, you can keep improving stuff you like for a good while until you reach an actual upgrade, and as stated before, friends make it fun.Grab it when it's cheap, 10 bucks is too much, but 5 dollars seems alright for a fun game with friends.Single player hurts to play through, but is tolerable. Though I wouldn't reccomend playing through it, its a standard "dark and brooding hero" storyline with rebel mumbo-jumbo.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												Well, I'll say I was skeptical when I bought this game as a lot of people were knocking it but honestly I'm enjoying it quite a lot! It is a tad bit buggy fighting in tight places, and somewhat frustrating starting out but once you advance a little and get your stats up it is fun despite what people say. Just don't buy it expecting Skyrim and you won't be dissapointed lol. I'm enjoying the lively soundtrack, the voice acting is over all pretty good and for the most part the landscapes and visuals in general are great for the age of the game. The story line...well it gets you from one quest to the next, it is very much open world so you can wander as you please...however you can easily find youself severely out matched by wandering off the questline too soon. The controller support is a welcome addition as well (and yes keyboard commando types I am aware of your preferances... that works well also) when you have been mouse and keyboard gaming for over 30 years like myself trust me your wrists appriciate the change in position. If you do prefer the keyboard with your young healthy wrists :P then make sure to unplug any gamepads you may have as it defaults to controller without the option to switch if it detects a gamepad. So yeah...I'm running it in Windows 10 Anniversary with a mid range setup and it works flawlessly for me without any tweaking, so far no crashing or glitches. There is a somewhat annoying banner ad for the dlc's on the main page, but nothing of the sort in gameplay. People complain about the registration process...yeah...there is a checkbox to uncheck to skip this... if you just read lol. You do have to activate it...which is different.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Huge map, mediocre graphics, a decent battle system, a few bugs here and there, and extremely cheesy dialogue from a hero who just doesn't shut up.Despite that, it is a decent open world RPG if you are looking for one to kill time. Don't expect Skyrim with this in terms of lore, dialogue, and enviroment. One of the biggest and best things about this game is it's magic system, which gives you a huge amount of customization that a lot of other RPG's can take a lesson from.

												I think this was an improvement from the first game of the series. However, that doesn't mean this game is particularly good. The main character is still voiced awfully, but as a whole, the voice acting in this game is sooo much better than Two Worlds 1. But, the movement in this game is so unrealistic and loose. Controls are unnecessarily stupid too. To sprint you have to hold down RMB? Dafuq? The whole interface isn't very user friendly (in my opinion) either. I feel like if they got movement and controls better in this game, it would be so much better. But nah. I'd still recommend it though, as it is quite a fun RPG once you get used to it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												I seriously can't understand the hate, this game is a gem!Well, I've already played Two Worlds II years ago in the retail edition. I thought a lot of times about getting it on steam, but hesitated, bc of bad reviews (mostly the DRM). Downloaded > installed > did not run, but found that just Nvidia physX (located in the game folder) needs to be installed > started, made a very simple registration > the game runs perfectly, and still feels like in the old days!What is so great about this game? It is very creative, you have a crafting/weapon upgrading system, cool alchemy and witchcraft system, so it is not like a mainstream RPG. It has got it's flaws, no question, but there is one big thing: THIS GAME HAS A SOUL, IT FEELS ALIVE! And that's something I was missing in the TES games, which appear to be a lot more static compared to this one. Maybe not in the first prologue part, but after you start on the first island, you wanna get lost in this game just to find yourself after hours, wondering what time it is and when your birthday is. So many things to discover, and it makes even fun to read the books you find.Give it a try and thank me later!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I played the crap out of this game when it first came out, but only the multiplayer part. That alone is worth the 20 bucks as you can easily get 40 hours out of it. The spell system is so absolutely fantastic, it makes you wonder why you would play any other class. Probably spent 10+ hours building random spells just to see how they work. If only they had made the campaign multiplayer, this game would probably be one of the biggest hits ever.The single player game, for what little I played, was fun, and had a similar feel as the elderscrolls games. One thing I disliked, but came to appreciate for the level of detail, was getting hassled by guards for bumping into people on the street. Worth a play through if you are looking for a good solo fantasy game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												TL;DR: Played this game a while ago when it came out for Xbox 360.  I enjoyed it greatly until the game had some very poor performance and became unplayable.  The PC version works a lot better and is well worth the sale price.Rest of review:This game is poorly optimized, similar to The Witcher 2, with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ framerates in environments that look rather simple.  The performance issues aside, the game isn't gorgeous and offers little visual stimulation in return for your hours of progression.  The said, if you have a decent enough computer to run the game at a smooth 60fps, I imagine it'll be a fun game to toy with.The magic system is interesting.  You collect and combine cards to create magical skills to be used in the open world.  Don't misunderstand: this isn't a card game.  You simply use the cards to make stuff.  It's done fairly well and offers a lot of customization to your magical arsenal.The open world is fairly big but not as freely roamed as Skyrim or Fallout New Vegas.   There are a lot of linear, story-driven missions which get in the way of your exploratory experience.  However, you can explore a lot of areas in this game, and often, you are rewarded with both loot and side quests.Update - Dec. 2014: This game is now only $1.99, so get it.  Yes, it was in a few bundles recently, and that's probably part of why the game became so cheap on Steam.  The game is open world and offers a lot of exploration, but the game's performance is rather cumbersome to say the least.  If you have a decent enough machine for it, it's a decent enough experience to be worth the two dollars at least.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												While the combat is clunky to say the least, once you start finding books to unlock more spell types and abilities, the game becomes far more interesting. Combine this with a fairly basic crafting system and you have a decent RPG. I will say this though, there are several bugs that have burrowed their way into this game, whether it is ground polygons having flipped normals causing you to drop into an endless sea, accidentally getting stuck inside of a boulder inside a cave and having to re-load or having enemies getting stuck inside the environment. All and all, 6/10 here. It would get a 7/10 but the dialog is painfully bad at times and it completely takes me out of the experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Two worlds (the first game) had a huge map, yet it felt janky in every way a game can feel janky. Two worlds 2, has a tiny map, tiny islands, and for a game with guilds and a supposedly open world, does not have a great deal to discover. So in the end, both games have drawbacks. If you want a huge world, get the first game, just be willing to overlook 1000 different janky elements. If you want a more console, streamlined, slimmed down, rpg time, get this game. It looks better, plays better, and the content while significantly reduced, is of a higher quality level. 7.5/10 for the core game, 7/10 for the expansion which has better writing but a smaller world and a desaturated look that feels a bit washed out and unexiting visually. If you want a skyrim extremely-lite experiance, then you might find that here and have a damn good time.

Want anvils to rain down on your opponents and then use the anvils as a shield floating around you? become invisible and heal yourself in combat? That's just fine with the game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2012
												There is lots to love here for fans of the sandboxy-RPG realm, I suppose. I'm no authority on the genre, but the combat and magic system, for example, actually offers a superior level of fun in some ways than that of titans like Skyrim, IMHO.The musical 'mini-game' deserves a paragraph unto itself. It's Medieval Guitar Hero, with song arrangements that are actually quite inspired and a surprising joy to dabble in with the various bards-at-large in the realm.But at the end of the day, TWII seems kind of hamstrung by flat voice acting, repetitive sound design, and a maddeningly middle-of-the-road stance on how seriously it wants to be taken.At times this tongue-in-cheek, knowing stance works in the game's — and the gamer's — favour, giving it a disarmingly approachable feel for an 'epic' RPG. At other moments, however, you may find yourself desperately wishing it could make up its mind to stop pulling punches and fully embrace one way or the other.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I remember my first time playing this game. I was awestruck by the graphics and way the weapon system worked. The single player campaign offers a really intresting insight towards a great story that teachs you the basic concept of how attacks work (including how to make your own spells). Later on you may find yourself seeking to play with other players in the multi-player world. I could tell you that in the past, the town was lively with many players seeking lobby games and teaming up with new players. Sadly their are few players left who play in this multiplayer world as they look towards new video games being released. All in all, if your looking for a good campaign game to fight in then I would recommend this one but if your looking for a multiplayer experiance then you might end up being lucky if you find a few players or unlucky if you don't.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I would give this game a 6/10.The story...very enjoyable and entertaining side quests let you meet some very colorful characters.The Graphics...it is a bit buggy at times, but makes up for that in great scenery and wildlife graphics. I wish they had done as well with the human graphics, they are not horrible but could have been so much better. The water graphics... WOW the best I have seen in a game!The Fighting system...great balance of attack, parry, and defence that makes you think and time your moves for the best outcome. Very enjoyable!The Quest system...very in depth with clues along the way and map marks to help get you where you need to go.The Transportation...boats...horses...teleports...what else does one need? :)The Magic system...fun but complicated. You can create your own spell combinations using 'cards' that you find while exploring, hunting, and buying from merchants. It makes for some fun effects if you have invested in the skill far enough to cast what you have created.The Alchemy system...fun to experiment and make your own recipes that you can save and click a scroll to create later with ease. Water walking potion? Squee!The Crafting system...on the fly and anywhere crafting! Dismantle what you don't need for components and use them to upgrade the stuff you are going to use! And don't forget the dyes...what color do you want to wear? Find dyes at merchants and use them to our hearts delight!Overall I really enjoyed this game...though it is no Gothic, Dragon Age or Skyrim...it was still fun!Mods...I would recommend the Two Worlds Merged, mod. It expands the World into one large map with no barriers, adds more dye options, an in depth add on series of quests that are quite fun and add hours of gameplay...and many other features that add to the fun!

content:
Posted: December 4, 2011
												Grandiose Technik, vergleichsweise niedrige Hardwareanforderungen, abwechslungsreiche Szenarien und eine sehr gute Spielbarkeit mit ein paar Designschwächen und Balancingproblemen. Die Quests sind teilweise recht umfangreich und überraschend innovativ. Sehr gute dt. Synchro und ein sympathischer Charakter (was auch der dt. Synchronstimme von Daniel Craig zu verdanken ist). Die Story ist leider der übliche Fantasy Einheitsbrei mit ein paar Plot Twists. Im allgemeinen hat mich Two Worlds 2 jedoch sehr positiv überrascht. 8,7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Positives:-Fun and interesting open world with a good story line to say the least. -Extremely unique and original NPC's.-There are a TON of quests to do. I absolutely loved the first two worlds when i played it on the xbox. I literally played my mega high level character that one hit everything so much that the game corrupted, and yes it was buggy and i could go on forever about the bad aspects. -Two worlds 2 to me is a lot more appealing visually and im glad it didnt slack in anything because of it.-overall customization from the first two worlds to the second is still there. -Also the skill tree is identical. (I'd hope to see new skills if another is made)-Is the game is replayable? Very much so. All the time I find a badass staff or legendary crossbow and im on my warrior, or vice versa, and it really makes me want to try to get a similar item that would match my character. you just need to try every hero build and experiment.-Dismantling, Crafting, upgrading, and socketing items is great.-Alchemy is sometimes useful.-Magic system is also very unique and experimental.-I always love third person games but im pretty sure the first could be first person and third, it's been years since i played the first game.And here we go...Negatives:Honestly I'm not trying to polish poop here, the game is well rounded and playable but there's a lot of downsides.-Don't even get my started on horseback riding... -Still the same annoying voice of the character talking to themself, like oh "what's this?" upon finding an item. Characters say "did you miss me" when they run into enemies... ( it rains and he says "just what I needed") sometimes jumping in water they say " ooh atleast it's not cold." and then other times they say the water is cold etc. I love the game but damn it's just dumb hahaha.-I don't really care for the archery in this game its not satisfying to me.-Sometimes it's EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING if quests dont give enough information and you have to run around in an open world for literally an hour sometimes with no direction to try to find what you're looking for by constantly checking your map and equipment hoping for a clue as to where to go.(DLC especially) There's so many islands and often if you don't make good progress you'd never finish the game due to the lack of guidance.-When I play with direct x10 for me it's unplayable there's a lot of bugs.p.s.all right, so there's more negatives obviously like annoying ai's hand gestures repeatedly but thats kinda picky. Ofcourse you're all subject to your own opinion and right now I may be leaving out positives or negatives but i would not pay full price for this game. face the fact that it's not a perfect game but it has original and exciting aspects to it.DO-Watch some youtube clips to see if you'd like it first.-Buy this game if you get a chance to snatch it for 5 bucks or less.-Build epic heroes and experiment with game mechanics.-rate up my review if this was helpful at all. I really do love this game but actually thinking through it and putting down the negatives can only better the cause for future buyers and maybe things like this will be fixed if they ever make another.

												This must be the most underrated rpg ever. I mean come on, you have a huge world to explore, tons of quests and gorgeous graphics, even now when this game is suposed to be old. You can ride horses ( no, you can't fight from the horse's back but that is not so important in this game) they are easy to control, you can pick locks, you can upgrade armors, amulets, weapons and all this you can do it in your inventory . The recipe sistem for potions is amazing, you can create and name whatever potion you like. So try this game if you are a true rpg fan and don't compare it to Skyrim..come on you can do better than that :)))

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Two Worlds 2. Alright so I'm updating this after 2 years because golly it was bad. (This is still going to be bad.)So first off I'm going to base this review on the multiplayer primarily, even though it's not the main focus of the game. Just because of the 70+ hours, 60 or so have been in MP.When you first start MP you are given the choice between varying classes/subclasses. These include a fighter, ranger and mage with subclasses for the fighter and the mage. The subs change various skills and make the player more proficient in different combat styles/magic.Once you enter the your character you can join a European hub server. There are 50 of these each able to hold... 50 players? Not actually sure on that. But once you connect you'll join a small city market district where you'll see other players. From here you can look at shops and meet others. You can then proceed to create a lobby and select a game mode you want to play.As adventure mode is the one I've primarily played I'll be talking about it exclusively.It's a story based coop mode that has small-mid open world maps linked one after each other  based on a narrative. As far as I'm aware you are playing the role of someone serving the main antagonist of the singleplayer. Once you start a game it becomes a listen server and the one who hosted the game is now the host of the server.The combat in the game is... hard to get into, for some. I personally don't mind it, though I wish it did have a back step like the first one. (It might but I'm just blanking on it.) It's a lock-on style combat where one enemy is selected at a time. You are given 3-6 skills on your hotbar to use. In normal stance you can only use three, but holding down right clock changes them to another 2-3.Too lazy to continue.Had more fun in this than Fallout 4, and at least this is a RPG. 8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I wish there was more of an in between option for voting. I want to like this game, and I still do... But it really fell short of my expectations. I've only played about 4 hours at this time, so please take my review with a grain of salt.Pros:Modeling & texturingCharacter creationUI designCons:Weird controlsPoorly-written dialogueCliche plotAnimationPoorly written & designed in-game booksBugsI really thought the modeling and texturing of the game looked really professional. The game does look quite pretty. Even the character creation gives you great options for an attractive character. Most other games with character creation have ugly hairstyles, or a million options for ugly faces. Two Worlds II delivered on this point. However, that was about the extent of what appealed to me. As everyone else has mentioned, the controls are pretty weird. Not like it's the end of the world, but it takes a while to get used to.The plot (so far) is cheesy, dialogue feels really awkward, and the animation is clunky. Really clunky. I like reading the lore in games, so I naturally picked up some books. The writing was... pretty bad. I was surprised at the lack of proofreading, and as a graphic design student, the typography absolutely made me cringe. (Most people probably wouldn't care as much.)Combat is okay, but not great. They don't tell you that you can dual-wield swords, which I found out on accident. It helped me get through a challenging spot since it's pretty OP, so I guess that's the way to go. And stealth is okay, when it works. One of the bugs I had was walking into an enemy and repeatedly swinging without getting a stealth kill or doing any damage. Of course, he didn't notice me until I stood up fight normally, which was then no problem.In Conclusion:A small part of me still feels like Two Worlds II is a decent piece of entertainment, but it has a lot of problems. It absolutely is not on par with AAA games like Skyrim, so you will be disappointed if that's what you expect. I'll probably play more of it, but at this point there are a lot of better RPGs on Steam I'd rather play. If you're a die-hard RPG fan and love cheesy plots and dialogue, I'd say go for it. I just can't say that the game is for everyone.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												This game is not even close to be a masterpiece however it is still worth a RPG fan's time. The main campaign is pretty long although it feels a bit rushed at the end. The main story is quite cliche and the A.I, pretty dumb. Playing archer while trying to complete every side quest allows you to oneshot pretty much every important boss. The entire game is just the masterpiece of mediocrity.HOWEVER the Pirates of Flying Fortress DLC is an insane improvement. A gameplay is still nothing special and fighint repetitive as hell, neverthless the plot is great, the voice acting and charachters are really sweat, endings are fairly touching (...yet they don't really care about your previous actions, you just have a single decision to make and that's it). I do recommend buying the game together with the DLC in some sale (I got both of them for like two (bucks), play the main campaign if you really have no better games in your sigh or skip it and start with this great DLC (although you will decide to do this you will face a very challanging game if you won't know the gameplay).Oh, and the graphics are meh. Thankfuly the music has some hidden diamonds.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I have tried to get into this game.  I enjoyed the first one, mainly because I liked the storyline.  Combat was fun, as well.  The only thing that got to me in Two Worlds is the voice acting, which ended up being more comical than deal breaking.I wasn't eager to get Two Worlds II but I ended up getting it during the Christmas Sales not this past Christmas but the Christmas before.  Since then I have given it several tries, as a friend of mine has tried to convince me that it's worth getting through the first part of the game.Pros:1.  Great graphics... I have to give them that.  The scenes are gorgeous and they did a superb job with the modeling (though my guy looked like he was supposed to have gray spots in his hair, but it ended up looking like he had some kind of bugs attached to his scalp).  Armor modeling was awesome.  Their graphics team needs some kudos for their work.2. Uh...  "Better" voice acting?3.  Story line seems interesting.Yucks:The COMBAT!  Ugh!  Way too clunky.  No skill taken into account... it's click as fast as you can with the left mouse button and "hope" you hit them.  The AI is random so sometimes they run away.  You attack a boar and a gang of OSTRICH attack you.  WTF?  Really?  You're surrounded by beasts and you still can't even hit one, even though you're aiming right at it.  And don't even try to use a bow! The physics & targeting system is $#^@ >.<  Sneak attack is overpowered as h.e.double.hockeysticks, if you get lucky and are allowed to use it (seems you can only use it against humanoids) or are even ABLE to use it.  You can't have any weapons drawn to sneak because they mapped block to the same key as sneak, which is also the same key for run.   So you are blocking when you want to run, running when you mean to sneak... you get the picture.Okay... my point... don't get it.  Even if it is on sale.  You'll hate yourself because most likely it's going to be chosing between another game that is on sale.  Go with the other one.  I'm done trying.  Uninstalling forever.  Wish I could just give this dang game away.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I have tried to get into this game.  I enjoyed the first one, mainly because I liked the storyline.  Combat was fun, as well.  The only thing that got to me in Two Worlds is the voice acting, which ended up being more comical than deal breaking.I wasn't eager to get Two Worlds II but I ended up getting it during the Christmas Sales not this past Christmas but the Christmas before.  Since then I have given it several tries, as a friend of mine has tried to convince me that it's worth getting through the first part of the game.Pros:1.  Great graphics... I have to give them that.  The scenes are gorgeous and they did a superb job with the modeling (though my guy looked like he was supposed to have gray spots in his hair, but it ended up looking like he had some kind of bugs attached to his scalp).  Armor modeling was awesome.  Their graphics team needs some kudos for their work.2. Uh...  "Better" voice acting?3.  Story line seems interesting.Yucks:The COMBAT!  Ugh!  Way too clunky.  No skill taken into account... it's click as fast as you can with the left mouse button and "hope" you hit them.  The AI is random so sometimes they run away.  You attack a boar and a gang of OSTRICH attack you.  WTF?  Really?  You're surrounded by beasts and you still can't even hit one, even though you're aiming right at it.  And don't even try to use a bow! The physics & targeting system is $#^@ >.<  Sneak attack is overpowered as h.e.double.hockeysticks, if you get lucky and are allowed to use it (seems you can only use it against humanoids) or are even ABLE to use it.  You can't have any weapons drawn to sneak because they mapped block to the same key as sneak, which is also the same key for run.   So you are blocking when you want to run, running when you mean to sneak... you get the picture.Okay... my point... don't get it.  Even if it is on sale.  You'll hate yourself because most likely it's going to be chosing between another game that is on sale.  Go with the other one.  I'm done trying.  Uninstalling forever.  Wish I could just give this dang game away.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I played the crap out of this game when it first came out, but only the multiplayer part. That alone is worth the 20 bucks as you can easily get 40 hours out of it. The spell system is so absolutely fantastic, it makes you wonder why you would play any other class. Probably spent 10+ hours building random spells just to see how they work. If only they had made the campaign multiplayer, this game would probably be one of the biggest hits ever.The single player game, for what little I played, was fun, and had a similar feel as the elderscrolls games. One thing I disliked, but came to appreciate for the level of detail, was getting hassled by guards for bumping into people on the street. Worth a play through if you are looking for a good solo fantasy game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												I seriously can't understand the hate, this game is a gem!Well, I've already played Two Worlds II years ago in the retail edition. I thought a lot of times about getting it on steam, but hesitated, bc of bad reviews (mostly the DRM). Downloaded > installed > did not run, but found that just Nvidia physX (located in the game folder) needs to be installed > started, made a very simple registration > the game runs perfectly, and still feels like in the old days!What is so great about this game? It is very creative, you have a crafting/weapon upgrading system, cool alchemy and witchcraft system, so it is not like a mainstream RPG. It has got it's flaws, no question, but there is one big thing: THIS GAME HAS A SOUL, IT FEELS ALIVE! And that's something I was missing in the TES games, which appear to be a lot more static compared to this one. Maybe not in the first prologue part, but after you start on the first island, you wanna get lost in this game just to find yourself after hours, wondering what time it is and when your birthday is. So many things to discover, and it makes even fun to read the books you find.Give it a try and thank me later!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Full disclosure: I got this in a past Humble Bundle, and thank god I did, because this isn't worth whatever I did pay for it, much less the price they're asking.The graphics aren't bad, and the soundtrack, what I heard of it, is excellent, but who knows what the controls are and whoever designed it doesn't know things like how armor works and how to write an interesting story. The frankly awful DRM, which, while I understand their desire for demographic research and the ability to mail/email me promotions, I own this on Steam I've hardly stolen it, is just the cherry on top I'm afraid. I'm frankly not going to enter my CD key every time I play, especially not if I have to give some unknown thing a bunch of my personal information, including my physical address just to get the game I own out of demo mode. It's buggy and difficult to play (I got trapped halfway inside a gate three cutscenes in) and just, not that much fun.I really, really wanted to like it. The cutscene martial arts look like something straight out of a Chinese Period drama, all slo mo and flying through the air and fancy tricks, on paper it has an interesting premise, but it needs some serious TLC before it'll be worth playing.
