content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												A lot of people on steam will play a game for 10 minutes and judge the entire thing based on that. the first time i played this game my save deleted itself 6 times. 3 months later i tried it again on a slow sunday and when i realised my save was fine the next day i kept playing... and kept playing... and kept playing until my macbook overheated on the train. it's not the best game out there not by a long hot but if you have the time and the patience you wont be displeased. its combat can get boring at time but you can change your style so much in one playthough that it really doesnt matter i mean for example The Witcher was one of my favourite games when it was first released but the combat in that game had me in tears. There arent many games that will let you beat a Rhino to death with a sledge hammer or have monkey's throw♥♥♥♥♥♥at you while riding your horse (the horse is also broken). The game has this Instagram like filter over it when you're out in the open and it kills your eyes after a while but sometimes... just sometimes you'll lookat your scrren after you've fought your way through an entire field of warthogs and think... this doesnt look like♥♥♥♥♥♥on a stick.It's a game I'd advise anyone to play. I had fun playing it and these reveiws arent all about if a game is broken or has bugs or not because there isn't a game out there that has NO bugs what so ever. So give it a try... maybe buy it on a sale though... £14 is a little steap for a game that has made my punch my standing fan.

												I played this game few years ago when it was pretty fresh and I loved it. The graphics are amazing even by today's standard, the combat is really easy to master (but not necessarily every enemy is easy to be defeated), quests are really interesting without letting you feel that you are grinding and the story is well put together. 												Again I wish there was a middle option between recommend and not.Two Worlds 2 is a great improvement over the first game which was a complete crap hole. Its really "janky" kind of like deadly premonition. Iits got a bad but loveable feel to it. The dialouge is entertaining and some characters are well enough written. The combat system isnt amazing but it works. Actually, thats a pretty good summary about everything in this game. Its not amazing but it works.It wears out its welcome though. So many side quests and fetch quests and the main story quests never really go anywhere. I forgot what I was even doing half the time.I played about 18 hours of the game and didnt quit out of hate or rage. I quit out of.... disdain? I just didnt really care to keep going.If you are really in to open world action rpgs, and can get past some janky controls, then get the game on a sale. Otherwise you can pass this one up.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Two Worlds 2. Alright so I'm updating this after 2 years because golly it was bad. (This is still going to be bad.)So first off I'm going to base this review on the multiplayer primarily, even though it's not the main focus of the game. Just because of the 70+ hours, 60 or so have been in MP.When you first start MP you are given the choice between varying classes/subclasses. These include a fighter, ranger and mage with subclasses for the fighter and the mage. The subs change various skills and make the player more proficient in different combat styles/magic.Once you enter the your character you can join a European hub server. There are 50 of these each able to hold... 50 players? Not actually sure on that. But once you connect you'll join a small city market district where you'll see other players. From here you can look at shops and meet others. You can then proceed to create a lobby and select a game mode you want to play.As adventure mode is the one I've primarily played I'll be talking about it exclusively.It's a story based coop mode that has small-mid open world maps linked one after each other  based on a narrative. As far as I'm aware you are playing the role of someone serving the main antagonist of the singleplayer. Once you start a game it becomes a listen server and the one who hosted the game is now the host of the server.The combat in the game is... hard to get into, for some. I personally don't mind it, though I wish it did have a back step like the first one. (It might but I'm just blanking on it.) It's a lock-on style combat where one enemy is selected at a time. You are given 3-6 skills on your hotbar to use. In normal stance you can only use three, but holding down right clock changes them to another 2-3.Too lazy to continue.Had more fun in this than Fallout 4, and at least this is a RPG. 8/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I wish there was more of an in between option for voting. I want to like this game, and I still do... But it really fell short of my expectations. I've only played about 4 hours at this time, so please take my review with a grain of salt.Pros:Modeling & texturingCharacter creationUI designCons:Weird controlsPoorly-written dialogueCliche plotAnimationPoorly written & designed in-game booksBugsI really thought the modeling and texturing of the game looked really professional. The game does look quite pretty. Even the character creation gives you great options for an attractive character. Most other games with character creation have ugly hairstyles, or a million options for ugly faces. Two Worlds II delivered on this point. However, that was about the extent of what appealed to me. As everyone else has mentioned, the controls are pretty weird. Not like it's the end of the world, but it takes a while to get used to.The plot (so far) is cheesy, dialogue feels really awkward, and the animation is clunky. Really clunky. I like reading the lore in games, so I naturally picked up some books. The writing was... pretty bad. I was surprised at the lack of proofreading, and as a graphic design student, the typography absolutely made me cringe. (Most people probably wouldn't care as much.)Combat is okay, but not great. They don't tell you that you can dual-wield swords, which I found out on accident. It helped me get through a challenging spot since it's pretty OP, so I guess that's the way to go. And stealth is okay, when it works. One of the bugs I had was walking into an enemy and repeatedly swinging without getting a stealth kill or doing any damage. Of course, he didn't notice me until I stood up fight normally, which was then no problem.In Conclusion:A small part of me still feels like Two Worlds II is a decent piece of entertainment, but it has a lot of problems. It absolutely is not on par with AAA games like Skyrim, so you will be disappointed if that's what you expect. I'll probably play more of it, but at this point there are a lot of better RPGs on Steam I'd rather play. If you're a die-hard RPG fan and love cheesy plots and dialogue, I'd say go for it. I just can't say that the game is for everyone.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												This game is really poor. It looks quite good, although the combat system is actually full of odd glitches (weird jumping, drowning horses, poor interaction with the terrain). The main problem is that the plot and quests are insanely stupid. They make no sense in driving the story forwards (just putting hurdles put in a player's way and making them jump over them) and generally make almost no sense even in the game's terms (like a riding race you need to win, which is witnessed by no-one and in the end the current holder of the title just accepts whatever you say - "yeah, sure I did it faster than you!"; except you're not allowed to say this until you do "win" the race).I lost interest after about 10-15 hours and I won't go back to it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Although I usually try to give games several hours to draw me in, I find myself completely unable to do so with this one.  While the game doesn't look terribly bad, the animations and combat are abysmal at best.  The voice acting is decent but the conversations involve people going through one of two really low quality animations that just look like everyone is shrugging.  The default key bindings are incredibly odd and while they are rebindable, the way the combat works makes it redundant.  Going into stealth mode requires you to be standing completely still, as does blocking.  If you are moving at all you will instead start sprinting.  Targetting is hit and miss and I simply did not want to continue playing after the short time I had with the game.

So at this point I'd not recommend it to anyone with a mac at any price - no clue whether it is more stable on windows.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I really want it to be good. It's a huge game. You spend a lot of time in the begining on two main islands. Both feel pretty large. But if you zoom out of the map you'll realise theres a whole other island you haven't even been to yet that's five times as big as the other two islands combined. That's a great feeling.But oh my gosh is this game hard to control. You are so clunky! Everything is clunky! The melee combat is just gross to experience, range is either way too easy or way too hard and doesn't feel natural either way, magic is fun to mess around with but is also hard to use in combat especially if you have allies with you. That fire bomb spell doesn't know what the word friendly means. Doors are hard to open, jumping is grotesque, running looks and feels stupid especially if you prefer to carry a staff or polearm. Even the simplest actions like opening chests or picking up loose items is difficult. The loading times for containers is way too long and breaks up the whole game. I can't express enough how clunky this game feels. For a game with so much content, i'm straight up mad the fighting actually makes it unenjoyable to play.It's not even like this game is that old. There are no excuses. Especially since the first in the series had the same problem and they failed to fix it. And the fact the game freezes while it loads the next area sometimes is really annoying.On a positive note, this instalment improved upon the first Two Worlds in a lot of ways. The world is bigger, there are more kinds of enemies, cooler weapons, better story, necromancy is legal yay! However, it's just as clunky as the first game and really quite hard to play because of it. If the mobility in Two Worlds didn't bother you then you will definitely like this game. If however you're used to rpg's like Skyrim get ready for pure movement hell.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												So far, I've only played the so-called Network mode, which I guess it the 'multiplayer' online modes,  and I guess these quests are probably 'ment' for multiple players since the monsters/quests don't seem to scale very good for solo players, and considering I've seen about 3 people playing so far...  Example of this is on the 2nd mission 'through the mine' where countless groups of 5 or so skeletons/Dread Knights spawn from thin air and attack you - its slow going considering the method of running in, killing the ranged mobs and retreating to heal takes along time - its all possible solo until you start running into Tuloks which are practically invinicible not to mention can stun lock you easily, and there are two of them making it nearly impossible single player. Combat is fairly terrible, very minimal defensive options, no dodge and very poor block commands.  For melee characters its more of a spam attacks and hope affair.  At least in the original TW you had a backstep which helped significantly. I haven't played the Single player yet so I'll edit this review to reflect SP mode soon - as for network mode, avoid completely.  If your thinking of buying this game for the MP, do yourself a favor and don't.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Once a  long time ago when I was young (lets say the 70''s) there was agame that was a little different called Two Worlds.I was useds to the old way of playing RPG's and this new game was a little bit different.  I plaued it quickly and passed up a lot of side quests in my rush to get to the end.    This was a BAD move.  I soon got tired of getting killed so I put it aside.  Then a friend gave me a copy of theepic edition and Two Worlds Two,  I tri8ed to be patient but still had a hard time  with it because it made me think out of the box, so to speak.   At this time the company that was selling it would help you out if you just sent an email to support.  They would help you and even give you cheat codes like the horse race against the click to finish the starvation quest.     Now after all thes years I find the yo dated T^wo Worlds Two game on sale on steam.  I buy it and have trouble again with many of t6he quests like before but no help from thr conpany Except by there forum.  which I had  problems getting onto till just recently due to nissspeling the user name I used way back then.  I am not sure I will take up the game againas I found it difficult follow the main quest because I found my self stuck in a main quest.  For example when I was facing tge son of the fire God in the swamp my level 37 fighter did not last more than a few seconds.  The strat guide said "just let him chase you around till he gets low on power then finish him off.  So much for the strat guide's help.  I discopvered by accident that I could fire arrows at him fasat and they would stun him and thus I could kill him with my bow, albeit it did take a long while.    I now find my self apparently done in the swamp with no way out except to take the tunnel to the castle which gives ny character about 10 seconds of life.  Now this does not make sense because there is a whole big Island to explore so I must have skiped something in getting out of the swamp .    Just like when my level 26 fighter reached the top of the Tower of Fang's and could not even dent the guardian.  Once again the trusty strat guide was no help.  Having played this game long ago I manahed to get to New Athos by a combination   of walk on water potions and swiming.   When I  finished enough quests to kill the guardian I returned to the tower and killed him.Now you ask do i RECOMEND THIS GAME  i WOULD GIVE YOU A RESOUNDING  Y-E-S!!!.  It is  that is done a little bit differeently and a great game.  Some of the plot twists are hard to solve but I still liked the game.  I DDO NOT recomed the strat guide except it is nessasary to get back on the main quest or some of the more esoteric side quests.   The reason I have stopped playing was the possibility that would not be able to get onto the forum.  Even if I do it is not the same as the old days when they actually answered an emaik sent to support@ there wep site.Even with as the frustratin If I can get back on the forum I will give the game one more chance but I do not think I will get all the information I used to get way back when.  It will be agame that I will always like even if I do not finish it.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												As Two Worlds 1, Two Worlds II is a "so bad it's good". The voice acting, the animation, the dungeon design, the map design, the quests, the story are all mediocre to terrible. Why do i recommend this game then? Because if you are able to surpass the deep layer of bad design and glitches you will be able to find that it is a fun game, and most of the time it is pretty enjoyable. As said, the dungeon's layout isn't usually really good, but the enviroment design is on point. If you are an avid GDR player, you should give it a try, expecially becouse it is usually on sale.I will look forward to Two Worlds III, i liked the first one, and the second improved greatly on that on many aspects.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Single PlayerVery slow paced, slow traveling and there isn't anything really special or interesting besides the ability to craft spells, which some spells can be quite hilarious, but that fun factor is short lived. Also, there is no way to change time or fast foward time (i.e. Elder Scrolls games you can wait or sleep till the sun rises), so if you made it to a town and its night time where shops are closed and people are locked up in their homes you have to... leave the game running or explore.. or something till the sun rises. Lockpicking and pickpocketing is by little minigames that gets old fast. I can't bring myself to continue playing single player mode at all after an hour or two.Multi PlayerNon-shared loot can get frustrating if you are not playing with friends. A little more fast paced than single player with a lot of mobs to kill to keep you busy, and the extra mobs to help you level up faster. If you party with lots of people who like to summon mobs it will turn into a sh*tfest quickly. Also no more than 2 melee summoned creature per target; the rest of your summons will stand still and do nothing blocking other players since you can't walk through mobs.  There are different types of Multiplayer settings, I spent most of it on Adventure playing with a friend. I randomly disconnected and saw I was accused of using a trainer and got temp banned. I was low level and poor with little to no equipment upgrades, a lot of empty accessories (no gems), ran away from a bunch of mobs, while using lots of health potions and half dying all the time with my friend. There are better games to grind that have a much larger community (say ~50 players max online/ingame). BTW I didn't have any problems with registering (I have a router + firewall) and only gave general information (don't think they have to be true either).tl;drBought this game on sale for ~$5 including a DLC. Don't bother with this game unless you have friends to play with in multiplayer and at the really low price I got it for.4/10 (+2 sale price, +2 magic crafting system).

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												For its price, Two Worlds II is totally worth it.It's a bit slow-paced and travelling on foot can be boring (the main "con" of this game is it feels a little empty for an open-world RPG.)Oh, and the quest log sucks.But ignore this and enjoy all the cool features : good amount of diverse equipement, fits different archetypes (mage, warrior, archer (stealth isn't that good in-game so I won't say it fits the thieft archetype))Beautiful environements, nice sound and music design... Tons of side-quests, medium-sized skill trees... But wait there's more : the alchemy features allows you to combine whatever you want and create diversified potions, you can create your own spells and deconstruct useless equipement to upgrade the useful one.Definitely a good RPG that is worth every dollar of its price.79/100

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Two Worlds II is best described as a diamond in the rough, it's got some very fun gameplay and the spell creation system is amazing since you can combo spells to create things like anvil tornados. The voice acting is pretty good and the dialogue is genuinely funny, some of the animation are a bit unpolished and the enemy AI is serviceable but unimpressive, don't expect any advanced strategies here. The gear customization is great and each island you visit has a very different feel and look to it in terms of monsters and terrain.  However when you add it all up, this is actually a solidly good game.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												The game is fairly solid overall, and wondefully captures that big-world feel with a suprisingly solid sense of realism. I actually enjoyed it so far after spending a few hours on it.Sure, it does have a couple drawbacks (but what games don't?). Namely...- I feel the character control should have been made a lot tighter & snappier, without that silly sliding stop also. This would have made such a huge diff. It isn't super bad now, but it could have definitely been implemented better. I'd say this is my number one issue with this game.- The registration nonsense of the game is just a needless PITA (although thankfully it's only a one-time thing).But make no mistake about it, the graphics and atmosphere are absolutely spell-binding in this game, with solid character modelling and voice-acting. Story is so-so, passable.And for the low sale price, you won't find anything better out there, that's for sure.I'd rate this game a solid 7/10 as it stands (would have been higher with snappier character/combat control).

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Usually I go in depth with my recommendations, but this game is downright horrible aside from graphics / art.Combat mechanic is lackluster in impact, functionality and general engagement. Ranged and magic combat is weak, though magic has a unique touch of "mixing and matching" your own spells (i.e., placing fire element, water or ice element to a "shield-self" spell, causes different effects.) Though general combat targeting and visual impact is weak.Voice acting is sub par.Inventory screen, general interface (including options menu) is horrendous. Story is relatively interesting but broken by the horrendous game mechanics.It's got good concepts, but just terrible execution.In truth, I managed to finish this game once a long time ago when games were less... Impressive. But now that there are so many titles similar to this game out there, you can easily notice the flaws of Two Worlds II. Frankly, even the menu of this game is downright terrible. Despite the fact that this game was on sale for only 10$, I still recommend spending your money elsewhere.In short, it's a hard game to get into. But once you overlook everything.... You'll be able to have at least one or maybe (though doubtful) two playthroughs.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												There are some atrocious games on steam, some of which can be fun even if purely for the sake of how bad they are, But "Two Worlds II" Has got to be the biggest pile of trash I've ever had the misfortune of installing, After spending 1hr and 43m installing extra software that's needed for the stupid amounts of pre-loading crashes (Two Worlds II has stopped responding, Two Worlds II has stopped working, Two Worlds II Has encountered an error and needs to close), Such as PhysX from a year prior to the games original release (?!) I loaded into the game, The entry music was reasonably good but that is LITERALLY all that there is to enjoy about it, I've spent 24 minutes playing and about... 15 of those have been AMV's which were choppy, slow and beyond pointless, In the few moments I did get to play the game the controls were stiff and unresponsive, the camera control was overly sensitive (Even for me and I LOVE sensitive vision controls) and finally, combat... Can you even call it that? It's literally spam clicking until one of you is dead, there's no power attacks, there's no blocking, there's no dodging asides from hitting the jump button which... throws you in a random direction, usually towards the enemy you're trying to step away from and when you do end up getting hurt to the point you're about to die, The repetitive slam of that death tune is so incessant you'll end up voluntarily getting killed just to end it! All in all, If I could give it less than 1 I would.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Two Worlds II is another one of those promising games that take you absolutely nowhere.Gameplay is pretty solid, a 7/10 to say the least, combat feels good and responsive, actions are quickly performed, movement is smooth and you won't feel like it takes four hours to walk from point A to point B, even though the game world is large enough. There is a decent amount of habilities, magic spells, weapons and armors to buy and upgrade, but they are bound to level, meaning that they'll only appear on the game world once you reach a certain level, so if you want to relive the thrill of finding that overpowered legendary item in a chest deep down a cave full of perilous monsters, forget that. All you're gonna get are some lockpicks, a medium healing potion and a wizard's hat. And that is if you're a warrior. 'Cause if you play a mage, the game will make sure that there's a warrior helm in that chest, just so you won't be able to use what you find, a very common issue in modern RPGs.The game world is pretty large, composed of some three major islands, each one of them themed around something like middle-east, asian, and european designs of builduings, flora and fauna. There are plenty of quests to be done and there's a fair amount of NPCs, but none of them are memorable or even good at all. You're going to do a lot of running around, a little bit of riding around on a horse and even less sailing around, because you only get a boat too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ late, and that is another issue with modern RPGs. What the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with giving the player a ship from the start, so he or she can have some fun sailing around the islands? Anyway, It seems like there's a lot to do, but there isn't, really.Which brings us to the last point of this review and, by far, the worst thing in this game, not to mention the reason for me to not recomend Two Worlds II to anyone: The game suffers from a all-too-common rushed ending. The first major island will take you quite a long time to complete, since there's a lot to do and see. The second one, a little bit less. The third you can almost skip completely, since there's very little to do on it. The plot is also extremely rushed, with a huge deus ex machina right at the ending, throwing everything you've been doing on the main quest since the start out of the window.All in all, this game dosen't deserve more than a 5/10 and I would only recomend it if you, like me, have played pretty much every other RPG on existence. You might have some fun with it, but you would probably rather play something else instead.Gameplay - 8/10Soundtrack - 6/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 4/10Challenge Level - 5/10Replayability - 3/10

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												If you are looking to buy this game, please heed my warning.Do not step into multiplayer, if you can't speak german. Multiplayer servers are riddled with german people, who won't speak english. They understand english, but they just wont speak it.Now with that warning out of the way.This game is very good. Graphics are pleasant and not that demanding. If you ever get bored of bashing groms and doglike humanoid creatures, go to a town sit at a table, throw some dice or play a violin ! (yea you can do that)Magic system in this game are close to suppreme, I have spent many hours into this game mainly as a mage and I haven't even scratched the surface. You could make devastating spells that ricochet between enemies, everytime they ricoche they explode in 7 meter radius. Yeah that devastating.Melee system could need some rework. There are alot of fun moves in this game wich you can utilize to banish those pesky Necris back into their graves or maybe you could bash that friendly shopkeeper down a cliff. Who knows ?Archery is quite fun too, with the sniper mode you can mark several enemies to be shot with multi arrow. You can shoot elemental arrows fire, ice and poison. Distraction arrow is a fun mechanic, it summons a horrible creature at arrow location, who taunts your enemies.There are alot of loot to find and many creatures to be slain.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												If you are looking to buy this game, please heed my warning.Do not step into multiplayer, if you can't speak german. Multiplayer servers are riddled with german people, who won't speak english. They understand english, but they just wont speak it.Now with that warning out of the way.This game is very good. Graphics are pleasant and not that demanding. If you ever get bored of bashing groms and doglike humanoid creatures, go to a town sit at a table, throw some dice or play a violin ! (yea you can do that)Magic system in this game are close to suppreme, I have spent many hours into this game mainly as a mage and I haven't even scratched the surface. You could make devastating spells that ricochet between enemies, everytime they ricoche they explode in 7 meter radius. Yeah that devastating.Melee system could need some rework. There are alot of fun moves in this game wich you can utilize to banish those pesky Necris back into their graves or maybe you could bash that friendly shopkeeper down a cliff. Who knows ?Archery is quite fun too, with the sniper mode you can mark several enemies to be shot with multi arrow. You can shoot elemental arrows fire, ice and poison. Distraction arrow is a fun mechanic, it summons a horrible creature at arrow location, who taunts your enemies.There are alot of loot to find and many creatures to be slain.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												I'll admit that I didn't even make my way out of the starting area before being put off.  The entire game world felt wooden; awkwardly imposed cut scenes and voice acting, being restricted to a 'demo version' unless I 'registered' the game with personal details and a slight swaying of the camera when the PC runs (I've never been sea-sick before, but I'd imagine this game will cause nausea in some).  Maybe they take more time to accustom to, but the controls also seemed iffy: I tried jumping from a staircase, but had to try a few times before managing to succeed. Seeing the positive reviews on here there's probably more to this game, but there's something about two worlds that just makes me want to hate it; right down to the big bad who's outraged by his prisoner escaping, but is too busy to walk over and stop it.  Maybe if I'm bored some day I'll give it another shot, but I certainly wouldn't recommend anyone purchase the game.Edit: maybe it was an intentional part of the tutorial/escape sequence, but the AI seemed awful.  I was chased by a swarm of guards, then ran back past them a few times.  None of them could attack me unless I stood still.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2011
												Unlike most I was actually a big fan of the first Two Worlds and this was one of the few games I actually bought when it was released as opposed to waiting for it to go on sale.  Encounters can prove difficult at the start of the game and taking on more than one foe at once isn't always wise.  Once you're on par with the local wildlife at the start of the game is when Two Worlds 2 really starts to take off.  It's easy to forget about the storyline as you get sucked into all of the side quests that really seem to propel the game more than the story but it's just too much fun to stop.  I find nothing more enjoyable than venturing off into the distance just to find out what's there, destroying whatever stands in my way, and gearing myself along the way.  This game just keeps it coming like a 50 hour IV.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Two worlds 2, I was a bit worried about getting this one when i was looking for a rpg to play because of the bad energy the first recieved. However it came in a bundle deal for only about $7 and I say Iv'e definatly got my moneys worth. Sure some animations may be a bit clunky (however improves a bit with the dlc) the conenct itself is a real good time. At first things feel real strong against you with being 2-3 shot with the block being very strange mechanic only blocking a small amount of damage at the start and your shields do block projectiles but its more for apperance than anything you cant actualy raise to block. This being said the Progression system in this game made me love it especially spell crafting, using heaps of different combinations to make your own spell is pretty awsome(like anvil tornado or spraying projectiles with summoning).If your willing to overcome its buggyness to get use to the games many unique systemes(sailing for dlc, magic crafting) and want a rpg to kill alot of hours I reccomend go for it. Also if anyone know any other action/rpg or anything where you can sail id appreciate it

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2012
												Two Worlds II is a fun Action RPG for fans of the genre, with some interesting customization ideas that make it stand out from other RPGs of similar quality. If you are a Warrior or a Ranger, you strengthen your equipment by Blacksmithing and Gems, if you are a Mage, you craft your spells by combining property cards into amulets and using them through a staff, and in any of the cases, you can Dye your armor in various colours or take advantage of Alchemy to brew special Potions.The game is precisely reminiscent of The Witcher, both in being a 3rd person Action RPG with customizations, and in the Main Protagonist, whose style of humor and even his voice, may remind you of Geralt of Rivia.On the down side, the game does suffer from quite a few bugs in specific quests and some things may also look unpolished. And typically, the ending may feel dissappointing depending on the player.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2011
												Tons of content in this RPG.  I have yet to finish the singleplayer, but so far it is a lot of fun.  Voice overs could be better, and some of the face models are ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Multiplayer is a good time, has a seperate campaign to play with your friends, along with deathmatch and duels.  There is a multiplayer feature I have yet to touch, which is where you buy a village and can profit from the buildings you create within it, I believe you have to fend of creatures as well.  There are plenty of armor types to buy and trade in the multiplayer world.  I am also aware that there is a very broad magic system, as far as creating your own spells.If you enjoy RPGs get this one, if you don't have the $50 right now, you can wait for a deal, and live.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2013
												Two Worlds Two has a dumb name, as a consequence of being a sequel to a game with "Two" in the title, and is generally pretty weird. It's huge, the magic system is crazy, the world is beautiful, and there's a few interesting quests and plot elements, but even still it's not for everyone. There's some really terrible voice acting, which is a bigger knock than you might expect as the worst character in that regard is the main character. Each world area you get to is deceptively smaller than the previous, also, slowly constricting you and forcing you down a main quest path that stalls in the final third of the game. The combat isn't 100% great, either.Even so, I feel it was unfairly maligned thanks to its predecessor's reputation and an overly-long tutorial. If you can get ahold of it on the cheap, I'd say it's worth trying out if you're a fan of open-world fantasy. There's a chance you might fall in love with at least one element of this weirdly disparate game.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												I played Two Worlds (one) on the Xbox360 years ago.  I was bored waiting for Elder Scrolls Online to come out and I picked this title up on the off-chance it was better than the 1st one (and I recall the first one being fun).The $20 spent is well worth it.  It truely is an "open world" sandbox type game.  There is an underlying story (which is very well done), but if you just want to run off and explore, its fun and possible.The game runs in full HD and is very visually stunning.  I especially like the late afternoons and the way the sunligh interacts with trees and shadows.  Fans od Dragon's Dogma (another highly underrated title from Capcom) and Skyrim will be very satisfied with this title.  I honestly find it mre fun than Skyrim, though Two Wrolds has none of the "community support" of a Skyrim.I highly recommend this game for "out-of-box" experience, and it just gets better.  Can't wait to pllay the "pirate add-on" that I got with the "Velvet Edition"Tips:  1. Print the english portion of the manual found in the \SteamApps\common\Two Worlds II folder.2. PLAY in DX10 mode (choose as the opening dialog box)Open in pdf reader and print JUST pages 25-40 (for english) .  I played for a while before I discovered this.  There is no keyboard reference under options menu to reference.PROS: Great graphice and animations (PLAY in DX10 mode)game engine beautiful and diversenon-linear with exception of the main story lineupgrades (weapons and armor), crafting, gambling, sailing, customizable magic system, horseback riding, and many other things to do besides "kill-grind-kill" (what other game lets you play a guitar?)Has some co-op multiplayer (though I haven't tried it yet).CONS:It's not Elder Scrolls online (j/k)a few of the actions require "click here to confirm" actions which is a bit tiresome.Enemy AI can be fooled to seperate enemy packs by running away to "thin the herd" before killing individually.Archery "auto targeting" can be frustrating

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Two Worlds II is a solid, if a bit generic, single person RPG.  I have seen comparisons to Skyrim/Elder Scrolls games and will say that I think that is somewhat of an unfair bar with which to compare it.  I played the original Two Worlds and found this to retain some of the nice features of the original (making all materials usable, the ability  to tailor weapons to work best against specific foes) while dumping some of the lesser features (the horse combat, which, while a neat idea, never worked well). The ability to tailor the character skills to my style of play was a definite plus to the game, allowing me to make the character I wanted as opposed to following a class type.  The main storyline was decent, but the side quests, while sometimes fun, were rather generic.I found the exploration in this game to be rather limited.  Although there were several places the hero could go immediately, there wasn't much to discover at each location.  I was also somewhat disappointed to find that the last island, while seemingly huge on the map, was very limited in where the character could go.I actually found the Pirates of the Flying Fortress expansion to be more enjoyable than the main game.  Although the gameplay was very similar, I felt the plot that was more absorbing for me (perhaps it is my deep-seated longing to be a pirate of old).  The humor was great and the side quests seemed more engrossing than the main game.All in all, I can recommend this game when purchased at a discount for someone who is looking for something familiar and somewhat generic to waste a bit of time and follow a story.  I would recommend against it for someone looking for a cutting edge game that has something new (or, had something new 3 years ago).

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												I'll admit that I didn't even make my way out of the starting area before being put off.  The entire game world felt wooden; awkwardly imposed cut scenes and voice acting, being restricted to a 'demo version' unless I 'registered' the game with personal details and a slight swaying of the camera when the PC runs (I've never been sea-sick before, but I'd imagine this game will cause nausea in some).  Maybe they take more time to accustom to, but the controls also seemed iffy: I tried jumping from a staircase, but had to try a few times before managing to succeed. Seeing the positive reviews on here there's probably more to this game, but there's something about two worlds that just makes me want to hate it; right down to the big bad who's outraged by his prisoner escaping, but is too busy to walk over and stop it.  Maybe if I'm bored some day I'll give it another shot, but I certainly wouldn't recommend anyone purchase the game.Edit: maybe it was an intentional part of the tutorial/escape sequence, but the AI seemed awful.  I was chased by a swarm of guards, then ran back past them a few times.  None of them could attack me unless I stood still.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												After 24 hrs here is my thoughts....Pros: Nice to look at. Open world, large open enviroments to explore.Magic system is interesting.Crafting is simple and effective.Has a good dose of humour.It doesnt make things too easy - you can stumble into places and get a shock (reminded of Morrowind a bit)Cons:Melee combat isnt great. You can play a melee (in fact i am cos i just dont do mages) but you feel like your thrashing about more than tactically fighting. Once you learn that you can easily get behind larger beasties it gets easier.Some of the resistances on mobs are not obvious (dunno if im just missing something but the manual tells you sod all ).After 24hrs i still dont know what some of the stats on weapons mean. Nothing in the manual.Basically, its a pretty good solid action rpg with a nice world and decent visuals. If some of the finer points were more obvious, ie stats it would be better but this is not going to ruin the game.If you enjoy the likes of Skyrim and you see this in a sale then for sub £5 you will get alot of gameplay and some decent RPG hack n slash.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												This game is a mechanical disaster. Almost none of the actual design elements are working. Starting with the dull combat which is even worse than it was in the Gothic and Risen series. The pointlessly simple lockpicking mechanism. The awful ui and inventory system. Crafting is one of the things which are actually useable. Graphics-wise the TW2 is decent, it runs well. The world itself while a generic run of the mill fantasy setting, contains a few interesting locations. Dialogs are uninteresting. Quest tracker is hard to use.The game has many faults in my eyes, but the worst is the combat. Amalur had similar issues with dialogs, quest tracking and world, still it had great combat. That one aspect made it a great game. RPGs often prioritize story, exploration, progression above combat, which is good, but you still have to offer a decent fighting mechanism because it is what you are going to do half the time. I can hardly think any of those respected rpgs which have a really good combat system. The second Two Worlds is neither a decent rpg or an enjoyable fighting game.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Even though I only have 0.7 hours, I played for quite a bit on PS3. And I put in a looot of time into Two Worlds.This game is like having to truly love that fat girl for her personality, and not care that shes a whale. Jokes aside, they improved a lot and this game has a lot of things other games dont do. You can do things like infiintely upgrade a weapon, so if you like the look of a certain weapon but its one of the early beginner weapons..you can just keep upgrading it. You can make your own spells, and you can come up with all sorts of crazy spell combinations. I was watching videos of people with their spells, some guy made a killer AoE spell, another guy made a spell that summoned like 20 golems. You can dye your armour, so that everything matches. Like when you find two armor pieces that would look good together but they dont, because completely different colors. As for the whole liking the fat girl for personality comparison..Games terribly optimized. Character models look bland. Animations look terribly awkward. Voice acting is terrible, as well as the dialogue. And the one thing I hated the most about the previous entry, NOTHING EVER RESPAWNS. By the time you build this crazy insane guy up, theres not much left to test him out on. And everything you do test him out on, well that leaves one less enemy in the world. There is co op that you could do this on, but do I really want to run through the same stages over and over and over again doing the same stuff? They shouldve just made the co op a free roam adventure.Overall, I wouldnt recommend this game. Too many things to look past. But if you dont mind all these things, then get it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
Product received for free
												Read this review with the thought in your head that I am reviewing in 2017, 6 years after the release of the game, and have recieved the game for free. In all honesty, this game was completely overshadowed by the graphics, gameplay and storyline of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Also released in 2011, Skyrim got all the attention because of it's vast world and extensive storyline. Two Worlds II doesn't have an open world, and more of a single dedicated storyline. The first Two Worlds game was also a pice of junk in all honesty, so I didn't expect much at all from this game. As a second point, 20 dollars is WAY too much to ask for this game right now, but I think $1.99 is a "Fair" Price. This is worth checking out if you want terrible game to find glitches in and mock it's "terrible" graphics by today's standards. If you have gotten it FOR FREE, why not give it a try. But if you haven't, DON'T pay 20 dollars for this, get Skyrim for 5 dollars on sale.

content:
Posted: February 28
Product received for free
												What should have been a good game is ruined by a defective copy protection system, (why did they even bother putting it on steam then?) occaisionally it bugs out and demands you re-re-re-re-re-re-re-re-enter your serial number.. on top of that, when it demands the serial number, it also re-demands that you register.. which if you already registered .. will fail. On the other hand if you manage to login past the stupid protection, the game is ok to play with passable graphics. Just dont log out until you beat it or get sick of it, or you may have to re-enter your serial YET AGAIN and if you get your registration info wrong the second time dont expect to be playing it very much...Ironically I read an article indicating there was a no-cd hack made for this that removed the serial check, and fixed some other game breaking bugs too. The orignal makers of the game couldn't do this for the steam version... why exactly? Who knows. But they lost my respect as a result.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Honestly, I can't say that this game is all bad. It did have it's moments (I bought it for console originally so I have about 50ish hours logged there as compared to here). But, long story short: If you want a game that is a full release yet feels like an alpha release, be my guest and buy it. Otherwise, don't. The controls are a bit odd and hard to get used to. The dialog is, quite frankly, stiff and unemotional (especially for an RPG). And while this game may add some very cool concepts to the gaming industry, it does not deliver as it should. Oh, and don't even get me started on the tutorial that takes around an hour (or more) for most people. And that most of the "map" is completely unavaliable for you to play on (and I mean the non-tutorial actual game map). Overall, it is not worth a buy. Not even on sale. But, if you want to, buy the game and see for yourself. As I said earlier, I have 50ish hours of this game logged into my console. It's an interesting romp in a strangely unfinished world. This game HAD real potential. I only wish that it was fulfilled.4/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Used to play this on Xbox 360 when it first came out. My buddies and I were in high school at the time, and while very messy, the first game had a certain charm to it.... we all bought the game and spent hours and hours in the multiplayer, forming our own little guild and buying a village and pooling our resources for it's upkeep while getting our sh** pushed in by the overpowered monsters that would threaten it at times.... I had so much fun with this game and for those who give it a chance, it is a great title and lots of fun to play, both multiplayer and singleplayer...... however...I refuse to recommend this game on steam when it wont even start. I looked up many, many solutions to this instant crash on startup. I was met with endless replies of "can someone recommend a different method, because this didnt work for me..."No matter how fun a game is, I will never recommend it if you have to spend hours trying to jump through hoops just so it MIGHT work... I loved it on 360, and if you have one laying around, give it a try... but do not purchase it for the PC. It's broken as hell and it confuses me why comapnies are allowed to release things that do not work, like this....  tl;drConsole version = Play it!PC = Waste of time and money as it wont even start. Save your money.One of very, very few benefits of console gaming, I guess.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2012
												Two Worlds II is worth it's wait in gold. This is the game that Oblivion should have been. Fantastic cutscenes, expansive areas to explore, real animals to kill. No more there being only deer, boar, & bears. You can fight a wide variety of enemies, not just animals, but also creatures that you wished were in other games. The leveling is incredibly fun and custimizable. Your enemies do not level up with you, but rather you can enter an area where you will easily die, making this game just as it should be: a real RPG.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2012
												This game has a really good magic system, a creative storyline, a freeform character building system, a fairly nice crafting system...And as long as you don't play the last chapter, a really good game! The game is amazing, weaves an interesting and complex plot that build up towards an amazing apex.... but right before you reach it, it does a stupid twist, and instead of wrapping up in a nice neat bow, just creates a thousand plot holes. Honeslty... get the game, enjoy the game, but stop and go get wrapped up in a different game before going into the final chapter (the return to gandahar's castle). That's the way you'll enjoy it most.

Posted: May 13, 2016
												This RPG has many flaws, but I kind of ignored them. Why? Because it's really immersive, great music and the environments are amazing. Plus the water / wave physics are pretty cool. I solely played this game to explore around and enjoy the world.If you're like me, get this game, but beware of silly voice acting, funky animations (that running..) and probably just an average RPG in the greater scheme of things. Still for me this was just really immersive, and I love immersive games. ^^

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I've played about an hour, but this game feels like an early beta, but has been out for a long time.From what I've played, here's what I've found:Pors:~ Was on sale for $3 (luckily or I'd've returned it by now)~ Good 3D graphics for its time~ Cut scenes are decent~ Voice acting isn't too badCons:~ Horrible and ugly UI; looks like it was made for a 1995 game~ Requires full name and address to register game even after the CD key is input, otherwise it only allows demo play~ Opening inventory unequipts everything equipted~ Combat system is meh~ Super linear world, definately not fun for Elder Scrolls fans, but maybe okay for Dark/Demon Souls/Boodborne fans~ Poor AI, friendly and enemy~ Character customization is bad; I made him (only males can be made) tall, but it kept his lower arms short and tiny hands so he looked like a T-rex forever

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible. How it got a 75 average on metacritic or any reviews above a 20 are beyond me. And no, I'm not dumb enough to buy it, it came in a bundle I bought for something else. Its combat is some of the worst, most unfun, embarassingly bad combat that I have ever seen in a game. Ever. The combat is so bad that it is comical and is unbelievably generic with no substance at all. The combat is like something two college kids would program for a indie game that is aimed at parodying other third-person rpg games. This is not real. This is a laughably bad imitation of much better games.In actuality I want to send a letter of thank you to this games developers. I have so many games I need to play/finish, around 90+ installed, that I was hoping that this game would suck so I could just uninstall it and get back to my other good games. So thank you devs. I don't have to worry about having another good game to play through.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Got this game on sale, which I'm happy about.  Graphics and voice acting aren't great, and neither is combat.  There's a fair bit of different RPG mechanics, but the fact that they're still explaining them after over an hour of playtime is ridiculous.  There's not too much character customization either, and you're stuck with playing a male character (sorry ladies).  This may also be the only game where the provided CD key is actually asked for, and you're required to register with the (I assume defunct) company that made this game.  Nothing special and best if avoided.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												Very complex gameplay, with a story that is very understandable. To enhance the excessive visual cutscenes, they do not include subtitles. They know the best fit for most gamers who are playing the game, as they strongly advise to listen to the dialogue and they strongly yet secretly take away the subtitles option. Here's a quick "snippet" of the dialogue:Rolinrdirrearfear: "[insert some wierd latin name], you need 2 git sum steeel."Me: aight. wait wher cun i find steeelRhhhlifnskfdir (same character, just ilustrating the complex names u kno): u cun get it in teh hasdhf dshjfaldinir.Me: wait tf lol wher iz it thoRblahblahblahdir: you can get it in the (didnt know what he said) where u crush it n stufSpeech choices at that point: 1. wait tf lol wher iz it tho2. k kool c ya Very exciting.Oh, the gameplay, you say? you want to know what the gameplay is like?Picture this in your mind: Skyrim on aids makes a baby with Dark Souls, which has dyslexia and ADHD. The result: Two Worlds II, aka Skyrim and Dark Souls's baby, which has genetic aids mixed with dyslexia and ADHD. very depressing.Its like if John Cena had no muscles. he would still be beautiful (no homo), but he wouldn't be that effective on getting the job done.enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Review as of 10/1/2016:Had to update this review due to comments about me not mentioning the singleplayer. I never touched the singleplayer due to a friend of a friend trying to convince me to buy it because it was so cheap and he referred to it as an MMO. I am sure the singleplayer is where the game "shines," but the combat style that I experienced in multiplayer I would assume is exactly the same in the singleplayer as the multiplayer.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Do not buy this game. Yes it is on sale for very cheap, which is extremely appealing, but do not do it. The multiplayer is the strangest broken mess I have ever seen in a game. Trying to play with about 8 people and after 20 minutes of trying to figure out how to actually leave the starting area of the server, one of my friends finally figures out how to actually play a quest, but sadly only me and him could play it. The combat is decent I guess. The inventory system is very laggy and can be confusing at times. I do not recommend this game at all. I am honestly surprised the devs have kept the servers going for this game.

												The graphics are ok but the controls are very bad. Also the menus only have a few options visible at once and force you to scroll to see the rest, but it doesn't scroll smoothly.
